A gallwn i'n hoffi nhw.
Mae pobl yn dod o'r lle.
A chydw i'n gwybod, gyda phraegwyr o'r lle,
a byddwn yn mynd i gyd yn ffyrw neu ffyrw, yn ystod y ddwylen,
a byddwn yn mynd i gyd yn ffyrw neu ffyrw.
Wel, dwi ddim yn credu bod nhw'n bwysig i mi yn fwy.
Roeddwn i'n fwy o fyw.
Ond roeddwn i'n mynd yn ystod yn ffyrw neu ffyrw a ddod o'r gam.
Ond roeddwn i'n gwybod gamanfaganau,
a byddwn yn ystod y pethau yma,
fel y pethau ymgyrch ymgyrch.
A roeddwn i'n mynd i gyd i ddod o'r gam gydag y gydag y gam.
Roeddwn i'n gwybod y gydag y gam yn ystod y ddwylen,
a'r un o'n oedd yn Cincinnati, yng Nghymru.
Roeddwn i ddim yn gwybod gydag y ddwylen,
felly roedd fy marn i'n dweud,
a dwi'n dweud, why don't you go to Montreal?
You know, all the boys in the office up in there go there,
and you can have a holiday there.
Well, I said, if I'm going to Montreal,
then I may just as well go down through Chicago
and down through Cleveland and take in the Manvagani,
which I did.
I could tell you about my night in Chicago too.
I'd always had visions of Chicago having gunmen and everything else,
and I went into this hotel.
I wanted it close to my station where I was going to leave,
so I didn't want to lose my way.
And sitting in the hotel lobby,
when I went into the hotel lobby to register,
I had looked all around and here were these fellows sitting in chairs
with some of their hats down over their heads,
and I could visualize behind all those hats were all these birds,
and they were all gunmen and all.
So I went up to my room and I stayed there.
I went up early, about 8 o'clock, and I stayed there all night.
That's my first impression of Chicago.
The next day I caught the train and went to Cleveland.
And we were all taking it all in.
Of course, Cleveland, the lobby, was sitting in there,
and the bellboy, or this was a joke on the bellboy, I suppose,
they asked him to call, please, Mr. Jones.
Mr. Jones, Mr. Jones, Mr. Jones.
Well, here was dozens of them all in the lobby, all of them Mr. Jones.
That created a little fun.
And then, of course, I walked along the lobby
and I saw this lady sitting there, and I spoke to her,
and I said, you had lunch.
And she said, no, I haven't.
I said, let's go and have lunch.
I don't want a big lunch, or maybe you don't.
She said she didn't.
So we went down to a lunch place and had a little lunch together,
and four years afterwards she married me, or I married her.
A wedi dod i'r gymhanfod hi hefyd?
Ie, ydy'r gymhanfod yn Cleveland.
O'ch eich dai wedi dod yn oed i weld y gymhanfod?
Ie, she came from Milwaukee and I came from Winnipeg.
A chi wedi bod mewn gymhanfod gyda'ch gilydd ar ôl ni?
Pretty near everyone, yes.
Well, there's a few that didn't go.
Different ones we had to miss.
Eurica, New York's a little too far.
Los Angeles, we missed that.
We've been down to near every one of them since then.
It's not the last two years we haven't been able to go.
Would you say that attending the gymhanfa is probably the main way
that you now keep in touch with the Welsh way of life?
I would think so, at least it certainly gives it an impetus,
because as you know, the gymhanfogani weekend,
always on Labor Day, and there's always a Friday night celebration.
It's usually a banquet or something of that sort.
Saturday is Northam Llewyn, and Sunday of course is always the gymhanfa.
And then Monday of course, a holiday and everybody's gone.
Sunday night a lot of them leave because they're close enough
and they start on their way home.
I think it does. It draws them together.
It really is something.
I'll tell you, the first time I went into this, they had this in Brounstone Church,
I think it was, what's the name of the man,
the big money man in Cleveland.
This church had a 4,000 capacity, I believe.
I went in there and William Hughes was the conductor.
When he led them and started them off in there,
I forget exactly what hymn they were singing.
But it certainly gives you a creeping feeling.
You feel your hair is standing up,
and it's remarkable to hear 4,000 people,
or close to 4,000 people standing, and starting to sing,
all at the same time, and all of them.
By the time they got to the second line, they were all in line, all in time.
It was wonderful. It is really, of course there's other things too,
which would tend to bring the Welsh people together, I suppose.
But those things are too big, they're too wide,
and they're too expensive to go, unless you're a money person,
they're too expensive to go and spend all that distance.
You've got to make your holidays during the amount of time
so that you have time to get there and have the time to spend in there.
Ydych chi'n darllen pa tharae Cymraeg o gwbl, neu hanes Cymru?
Darllen y Ddrych, the Welsh American newspaper,
and we get the Envis.
That is about all the Welsh papers.
I don't get any of the local papers from Wales.
Ych chi'n darllen pa llyfrau cymraeg o gwbl?
As often as I can, I struggle through them.
There are some Welsh books that I'd like to get,
and I can't get my hands on them.
They're probably duelled now anyway.
I've sent to the old country to see if I could get copies of them,
but I haven't received a reply yet.
Do you still keep in touch with any of the family in Wales?
I have no family in Wales, you see.
You don't?
No, but some of my sisters, two of my sisters,
went back to Wales and then back to live in London,
and of course they've both gone now.
I have had a letter from my nieces and nephews,
and they took a trip through here and visited for a while.
It's quite interesting, but it's a problem
to know what to write to people you don't really know.
Why did your sisters go back to Wales from Canada?
Well, I read that their husbands went back there.
Both of them went back into business.
They were in the Bangor area?
No, my sisters were down there.
They were married in Winnipeg.
They met their husbands in Winnipeg.
After a period of years, some of their family had been born here,
and they went back to live in it.
One of them before the First World War,
and the other one after the First World War.
They went to live in London.
At least they went to Wales.
One of them was north Wales, and the other one to Llandaff.
They had their business there.
One was a grocery business, and the other one was—
I forget what the grocery business was.
Then they moved to London, and that's where they are both now, of course.
When did you move to Wales?
I've not been there.
You've never been to Wales?
No.
Would you like to go one day?
With conditions being cursed?
I think I would, but—
Well, I'm like Moses.
Moses was taken to the top of the mountain,
and so I am taken to the top of the mountain from reading books to see Liz.
He was shown the promised land, but he never got there.
I've been shown the promised land through books, but I haven't got there, not yet.
Do you feel that you know the country?
I do.
Well, no, I know quite a lot about it.
I've studied the geography.
I've read the history and all the rest of it.
It's quite a thing.
I think I know it pretty well.
And the family?
